articles.headline: E.U.’s Leadership Seeks to Contain Hungary’s Orban
articles.snippet: As the Hungarian prime minister built an “illiberal state,” creating a template for the far right, center-right leaders in Brussels did little to stop him.
articles.abstract: As the Hungarian prime minister built an “illiberal state,” creating a template for the far right, center-right leaders in Brussels did little to stop him.
articles.lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — As Prime Minister Viktor Orban steadily established an “illiberal state” in Hungary, dismantling the country’s checks and balances, stacking its constitutional court with loyalists and creating a template for other far-right leaders, a powerful group of European politicians took note.

articles.headline: Tax Breaks for Luxury Towers Spur Redevelopment, and Backlash
articles.snippet: Incentives granted to developers have helped fuel urban renewal around the nation. But some wonder whether they are appropriate for projects that cater to the affluent.
articles.abstract: Incentives granted to developers have helped fuel urban renewal around the nation. But some wonder whether they are appropriate for projects that cater to the affluent.
articles.lead_paragraph: Twenty years ago, it was unimaginable that a new residential high-rise would ever adorn the modest skyline of downtown Kansas City, Mo. But in the last three years, two luxury apartment towers have opened, and a third is planned.

articles.headline: As Elkhart, Ind., Goes, So Goes the Nation, and Elkhart Is Nervous
articles.snippet: As the recreational vehicle industry deals with President Trump’s steel and aluminum tariffs, signs of a downturn in Elkhart, Ind., have people worried.
articles.abstract: As the recreational vehicle industry deals with President Trump’s steel and aluminum tariffs, signs of a downturn in Elkhart, Ind., have people worried.
articles.lead_paragraph: ELKHART, Ind. — The tables were filled at the Chubby Trout restaurant and the local craft beer flowed. The Flippin’ Cow was packed too, with diners overlooking Simonton Lake. Small manufacturing companies were advertising for workers, offering health insurance and retirement accounts.

articles.headline: As Florence’s Power Nears the Carolinas, Residents Brace for the Worst
articles.snippet: A powerful Category 4 hurricane could linger along the coasts of North Carolina, South Carolina and Virginia, and deliver a huge life-threatening storm surge.
articles.abstract: A powerful Category 4 hurricane could linger along the coasts of North Carolina, South Carolina and Virginia, and deliver a huge life-threatening storm surge.
articles.lead_paragraph: [For the latest updates on Hurricane Florence, read Wednesday’s live briefing here.]
articles.byline: By John Schwartz and Timothy Williams

articles.headline: Education Dept. Reopens Rutgers Case Charging Discrimination Against Jewish Students
articles.snippet: The civil rights chief at the department, defining Judaism as an ethnicity, has reopened a civil rights case closed four years ago by the Obama administration.
articles.abstract: The civil rights chief at the department, defining Judaism as an ethnicity, has reopened a civil rights case closed four years ago by the Obama administration.
articles.lead_paragraph: The new head of civil rights at the Education Department has reopened a seven-year-old case brought by a Zionist group against Rutgers University, saying the Obama administration, in closing the case, ignored evidence that suggested the school allowed a hostile environment for Jewish students.

articles.headline: Edgy Investors Are Retreating From Risky Economies
articles.snippet: In stark contrast to the U.S., where a bull market continues, investors are pulling out of developing economies as the economic and financial risks mount.
articles.abstract: In stark contrast to the U.S., where a bull market continues, investors are pulling out of developing economies as the economic and financial risks mount.
articles.lead_paragraph: Cratering currencies, rising inflation, jumpy investors: A financial panic is again gripping some of the world’s developing economies.

articles.headline: The Metamorphosis of Silicon Valley C.E.O.s: From Big to Boring
articles.snippet: Technology chief executives were once admired for their force-of-nature personalities and daring. Now boring is the new black (or is it beige?). Except for Elon Musk, of course.
articles.abstract: Technology chief executives were once admired for their force-of-nature personalities and daring. Now boring is the new black (or is it beige?). Except for Elon Musk, of course.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Joe Barton, a Republican congressman from Texas, greeted Jack Dorsey at a congressional hearing last week, he sounded flummoxed.
